We provide a categorical approach to quantum mechanics. The approach is purely categorical, in the sense that it does not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are purely categorical and do not refer to Hilbert spaces or any other analytical structure. The approach is thus applicable to any consistent formulation of quantum theory.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been hypothesized to be the result of a single evolutionary transition from a free-living ancestor. To understand the nature of this transition, we compared the genomes of two distantly related species, Kudoa iwatai and Myxobolus cerebralis, to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of extreme degeneration of the cnidarian body plan. In addition, we show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals. This reduction in genome size is likely to have been accompanied by a reduction in gene content, and our results suggest that the myxozoan genome is also depleted in genes involved in development and cell–cell communication. These results provide insights into the molecular basis of the extreme reduction of the myxozoan body plan. (Show more)

Sperm cells are quiescent in the male reproductive system due to Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels, but become active once introduced into the low-Zn2+-concentration environment of the female reproductive tract. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops. We quantify how the variability of maize yields will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially in most of the world’s maize-producing countries. This increase in variability will increase the probability that the world’s major maize-exporting countries will simultaneously experience production losses greater than 10% in any given year. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savannas. However, the extent to which different species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in the field. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in determining the extent to which different species partition food resources. This information is critical for understanding the role of large mammals in the functioning of African savanna ecosystems. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and are closing. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for the CARES Act loans, but anticipate problems with the program.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the ocean. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the size-selective sinks of floating plastic debris in the ocean. The fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is one of the most intriguing questions in presolar grain research. The synthesis of SiC grains in stars is still not understood. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We show that the majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We also show that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The large difference in nuclear recoil loss of cosmic ray spallation products 3He and 21Ne enabled us to estimate that the irradiated objects in the interstellar medium were up to 30 times larger than the analyzed grains. Furthermore, we estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. These results provide new insights into the origin of SiC grains. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million more motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of parental care and domestication. Here, we show that the increase in energy availability is a key factor in the evolution of all forms of parental care and domestication. We also show that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is an important finding for understanding the evolution of parental care and domestication in mammals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. No treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process, and patients die within a few years after disease onset. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. We present here an in vivo proof of concept of the ability of the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 to mitigate α-syn pathology and to mediate neuroprotection in a mouse model of MSA. VX-765 was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study opens the way to a phase I/II clinical trial in MSA patients. This would be the first clinical trial in a synucleinopathy.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It is the primary regulator of blood flow, inflammation, and the exchange of oxygen and nutrients between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is a network of cells that is connected to each other and to the rest of the body by a communication system. The communication system is made up of a network of connections between the cells. The network is designed to be both local and global in its communication. The network is also designed to be efficient in the transmission of information.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis. In order to understand the pandemic, it is essential to have access to data on the pandemic and the public behavior that drives it. We have created a data API that provides access to a wide range of such data. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format, allowing researchers to easily combine and analyze them.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling and that it is crucial for the C-type inactivation gating. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in some K+ channel mutants. Finally, it provides a structural basis for the structural collapse of the selectivity filter. This work is expected to be of interest to the scientific community working in the field of potassium channels.

The gut of the herbivorous cow is home to a diverse community of microorganisms that are essential for the health of the host. This community is also important for the health of the microorganisms themselves, as they rely on the host for nutrients. The gut of the herbivorous cow is also a harsh environment, and many of the microorganisms that inhabit it are obligate anaerobes. Anaerobic fungi are a group of microorganisms that are important members of the cow’s gut, but little is known about their metabolism. Here, we report the discovery of a large number of natural products that are produced by anaerobic fungi. These natural products could be used as a source of therapeutics, or as a starting material for the synthesis of new compounds. This study provides a foundation for future research into the natural products of anaerobic fungi.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. However, the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is poorly understood. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social hierarchy establishment and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to discover optimal composite structures that seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The structures are digitally synthesized with multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct behaviors and seamlessly synthesized into composite structures. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The structures are also applicable to other fields, such as architecture, biology, and medicine.

Hemoglobin is the protein responsible for transporting oxygen in the blood. The hemoglobin content of blood is determined by the expression of the globin genes, alpha and beta, and the regulatory protein, chain-A (HBA1). The expression of these genes is regulated by a number of transcription factors, including BCL11A. Here we show that the expression of hemoglobin is also regulated by the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway. We show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of this pathway and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the regulatory protein, chain-A (HBA1), and that this results in a reversal of the adult hemoglobin pattern toward a more fetal-like pattern. This mechanism may be important for the regulation of hemoglobin expression in humans. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, is a recently identified form of cell death. It is regulated by cellular metabolism, redox homeostasis, and various signaling pathways related to cancer. In this study, we found that activating mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) function, highly frequent events in human cancer, confers ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction. Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The underlying molecular mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are not fully understood. Here, we show that the three major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate STIM1, which in turn activates ORAI channels. LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM1-mediated activation of ORAI channels. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM1-mediated activation of ORAI. This study provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension. Our findings may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases. (Show more)

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal lands. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in early-seral ecosystems, but that the policy failed to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The NWFP is a unique case study for evaluating the influence of policy on biodiversity.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Therefore, the development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility of the designed compounds. We show that the designed compounds are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens and are up to 56 times more active than telithromycin. The best compound designed by us is more accessible, exhibits higher membrane permeability, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. The design strategy is applicable to other antibiotic classes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular. However, the impact of this technology on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use before bedtime. This knowledge is important for the public health community, as well as for the millions of people who use these devices every night. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary is widely recognized as marking a global transition to a new climate. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope record of the YDB is consistent with terrestrial sources. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the YDB spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The YDB spherules are a unique and important component of the YDB record. They provide a link between the YDB and the 1.5-Ga crust of the Earth. (Show more)

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been extensively studied, but the impact of CTLA-4 in the adult is still unclear. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to spontaneous lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. This is not fatal, but it is accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. In addition, we show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice has opposing impacts on different autoimmune models. Thus, although CTLA-4–deficient mice have more severe collagen-induced arthritis, they are protected against peptide-induced experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. These findings provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. We also traced the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding, including the first independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialized herbivores was driven by the convergent acquisition of genes encoding enzymes that degrade plant cell walls. These results have important implications for our understanding of the evolution of plant-feeding insects and the origin of beetle diversity. This article is protected by copyright. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that, contrary to popular belief, larger populations do not enhance CCE. Instead, it is only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the design of experiments and the interpretation of results in the field of CCE. They also have implications for the evolution of technology in human societies. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is the apoE allele. APOE is a major protein of the brain and is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type of the brain. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of a protein that is a marker of senescent synapses in the brain. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. This hypothesis needs to be tested in future studies. (Show more)

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the innermost part of the Earth. It is a key part of the Earth's interior, but its formation mechanism is still unknown. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, this mechanism is not able to explain the formation of the inner core. We have found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core. This study provides a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. It also provides a clue to understanding the structure and anisotropy of the inner core. This study may lead to a better understanding of the Earth's interior. It may also lead to a better understanding of the formation of other planets.

Marijuana is a drug that is widely used, but its effects on the brain are poorly understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to be stressed and irritable. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human ability. It is also the most complex behavior we know of. How the human brain processes language is therefore a central question in cognitive science. Here, we use a state-of-the-art approach to link neuroscience, psychology, and computational modeling to reveal how the human brain computes the meaning of language. We find that the most powerful models of language processing in the human brain are also the most accurate at predicting how the brain and mind work when processing language. These results provide computational evidence for the fundamental role of predictive processing in language comprehension. They also suggest that predictive processing may be a general mechanism for how the mind makes sense of the world.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning. However, it is still in its infancy and faces many challenges. One of the most fundamental challenges is the instability of DL algorithms. In this paper, we show that this instability is not due to the algorithms but due to the problem itself. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where no algorithm can compute a stable neural network. This result has implications for the design of DL algorithms and the study of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community has been working hard to understand the virus and its spread. One of the most influential studies in this field is a classic experiment published in 1972. It is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, its design flaws were not noticed at the time and are only now being discussed. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a chronic disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae, which has undergone extensive reductive evolution. The uncultured human pathogen M. lepromatosis is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis and compare it with that of M. leprae. We find that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to infect the nervous system, whereas M. leprae has lost the ability to do so. This suggests that M. lepromatosis may be a more virulent pathogen. We also find that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Entanglement and entropy are central concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to the understanding of thermodynamics. However, the evolution of entanglement and entropy in isolated quantum systems is a very difficult problem. We show that the entanglement dynamics can be understood in the space–time scaling limit, by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has affected millions of people worldwide. The only currently available vaccine against COVID-19 is based on the inactivated virus. This vaccine is safe and effective, but it is not suitable for mass vaccination. We describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is safe, effective, and suitable for mass vaccination. This vaccine is temperature sensitive, which allows for its large-scale manufacturing. The vaccine is able to protect hamsters from the lethal challenge of the wild-type virus. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. It has been the subject of many historical studies, but the history of plague transmission is still poorly understood. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by human ectoparasites during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1347–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for studying the history of plague transmission in Europe. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy for the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased by the fact that brains of different species have different numbers of neurons. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size in amniotes is characterized by two major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The first shift resulted in the lowest neuronal densities in reptiles. The second shift resulted in the highest neuronal densities in birds and mammals. These shifts in neuron–brain scaling are associated with the evolution of high cognitive ability in birds and mammals. This study provides a more accurate picture of the evolution of brain size and its relationship with cognitive ability.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide. The development of new therapies is urgently needed. The molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Read more)

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, and they are the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin are key regulators of cell shape and motility. However, how it does so remains unclear. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We show that the mechanical torque that is induced by the presence of two anchoring points enhances severing by an order of magnitude. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of ADF/cofilin’s function in cells. They also provide a general framework for understanding the action of other proteins that are involved in the assembly and disassembly of actin filaments. This framework can be used to design new drugs that target actin dynamics.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and promotes greater hunger and desire for food and a willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may be a stronger feeding stimulus than glucose and may contribute to the increased prevalence of obesity in the United States. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement. However, the distribution of the ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the settlement was by multiple waves. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary targets of posttranscriptional regulation. One of the most common modifications in coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which can have a profound impact on protein synthesis. Here, we show that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can have a modest impact on translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our results suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA sequences and that this can have a small effect on translation. This is an important finding, as Ψ is the most common modification in coding regions of human mRNAs and is present in many viral mRNAs. Our findings may have implications for the translation of viral mRNAs in the cell. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, stronger social relationships, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust across a wide range of sociodemographic factors, and they are also robust over time. The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may therefore be a key factor in promoting healthy aging and sustaining social relationships.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in biology. However, the drivers of this pattern remain unclear. Here, we use a quantitative approach to test the relative importance of different hypotheses for the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. We find that the aquatic lifestyle is the primary driver of the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a failure of the host antiviral response at cool temperatures. Here we show that mouse airway cells infected with rhinovirus exhibit a more efficient antiviral response at 37 °C than at 33 °C. This difference in the magnitude of the antiviral response accounts for the temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication. Our findings have implications for the development of rhinovirus vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces. This mechanosensitive system is required for attachment to surfaces, and results in a positive feedback loop that promotes long-term attachment and virulence. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This mechanochemical model may be a general mechanism used by bacteria to sense their environment. Understanding how bacteria sense their environment is important for understanding how they respond to environmental changes, and how they can be manipulated to develop new strategies for controlling bacterial infections. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticide concentrations in surface water and sediments. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has been detected in many animal species, including deer. However, the role of deer in the ongoing SARS-CoV-2 pandemic is unknown. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living and captive deer in Iowa. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 lineages in deer and humans are geographically clustered, suggesting multiple human-to-deer and deer-to-deer transmissions. Our findings highlight the need for a comprehensive understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2 in wildlife. This knowledge is critical to the development of effective strategies to mitigate the risk of SARS-CoV-2 spillback into human populations. This article is protected by copyright. The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder with no known cure. The disease is characterized by chronic inflammation, which is most often attributed to the presence of amyloid-β (Aβ) plaques and cell death. However, we show that soluble and oligomeric Aβ are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain and are responsible for the initiation of an inflammatory response in neurons. This neuron-specific inflammatory reaction correlates with the extent of microglial activation and mobilization, even in the absence of extracellular plaques and cell death. We demonstrate within disease-vulnerable regions of the human brain that a neuron-specific inflammatory response may precede the formation of Aβ plaque and tau tangle deposits. Thus, we reveal the Aβ-burdened neuron as a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a novel insight into the disease mechanism and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a new and unique archaeological record of economic exploitation of chickens in the Southern Levant, which shows that the practice was already well established in the fourth century B.C.E. and that it was fully developed by the second century B.C.E. Our results suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by ApaH, a pyrophosphohydrolase that prefers to remove the terminal phosphate of Np4 over the terminal phosphate of the triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated Np4-capped RNAs. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to prefer to remove the terminal phosphate of diphosphorylated RNAs over the terminal phosphate of the triphosphorylated RNA, is the predominant enzyme responsible for decapping Np4-capped RNAs. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. The immune system is the main target of sepsis, and the main mechanism of action is the production of cytokines. The main goal of this study was to evaluate the effect of citrulline, an amino acid that is a substrate of the enzyme arginase, in the immune system during sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing sepsis-induced Treg and MDSC expansion. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study could be a milestone in the treatment of sepsis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is the total amount of carbon and other elements that living organisms contain. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Here, we provide a census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and space, and the system’s dynamics are self-similar and critical, i.e., the dynamics are independent of the system’s scale. SOC is a very recent discovery, and it is not yet clear whether it is a universal phenomenon. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, including quantum devices. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be made a good conductor by applying a large enough strain. We also show that diamond can be made transparent to light by applying a large enough strain.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest for the development of new classes of fungicides. Here, we report the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, NCR peptides, which are expressed in the nodules of the model legume Medicago truncatula. The structure of one of the NCR peptides was solved by NMR spectroscopy. The antifungal activity of the peptide was demonstrated in vitro and in vivo. The mode of action of the peptide was studied using a combination of microscopy and mass spectrometry. The results provide a structural basis for the antifungal activity of the peptide and demonstrate the potential of this class of peptides as a new class of fungicides. The male–female reproductive axis is a classic example of a system in which the contributions of the sexes are intertwined. However, the extent to which the female contributes to the process of fertilization is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female contributes to the maintenance of sperm viability during the prolonged period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a model for understanding the molecular hand-off between males and females during the process of fertilization. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by binding to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on the surface of platelets. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The force-switched state is stable at physiological forces.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the impact of viruses on human health. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, and we find that viruses are strongly associated with many diseases. This database will be a valuable resource for the scientific community for years to come.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe simultaneously aerosol and cloud properties. This instrument is capable of measuring aerosol and cloud properties with high spatial and temporal resolution. We demonstrate the scientific potential of this instrument by analyzing the ACI process. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for more than a century. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the evolution of life on the planet. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has been estimated from isotopic data, but the results have been subject to question. We have developed a method to estimate the temperature of the surface of the Earth from the thermostability of enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the Earth has decreased over geological time.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, which in turn reduces a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work has important implications for the development of new antimalarial drugs. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and energy storage. However, it is not a good conductor of electricity. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and the metallization can be reversed by removing the strain. This work opens up new opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus are associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome during influenza virus infection. These insights may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of seasonal influenza outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases as it processes a sentence. Whether and how this structure is represented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to each successive word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power. This response is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be important for language comprehension and production.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for development and homeostasis. Axin is a key component of the pathway. We show that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level, but differ in their regulation. This difference is important for tissue-specific regulation of the pathway.

Obesity is a major health concern, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are poorly understood. Here we describe a circuit in the brain that may contribute to overeating. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. This effect is blocked by optogenetic silencing of LH neurons, and by lesions of neurons in the lateral hypothalamus or in the ventral tegmental area. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the lateral hypothalamus. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer the nitrogen cycle in agriculture is therefore a key goal for sustainable food production. Here, we have developed a synthetic plant-bacterial signaling system that allows the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal host. This system can be used to engineer the nitrogen cycle in plants, and we have demonstrated its utility in a cereal host. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to engineer the nitrogen cycle in plants and to improve the sustainability of agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest. It is also one of the most threatened. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are widely used to monitor and deter deforestation. However, the effectiveness of these alerts in deterring deforestation is unknown. We study a community monitoring program that uses remote-sensed deforestation alerts to train and incentivize community members to patrol forests in response to alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global health issues. We estimate the health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use and reductions of other anthropogenic sources of greenhouse gases and aerosols. We show that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C, thus limiting global warming to 2 °C. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is a heterogeneous disease with a wide spectrum of clinical behavior. The molecular basis of this heterogeneity is not fully understood. Here we show that the ligand–receptor complex of the ALK/ALKALS family of receptors is involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a key event in the history of humanity. However, the history of plague is poorly understood because of the lack of ancient DNA evidence. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this critical period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, hegemonic masculinity predicted less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can increase SOC storage in the world’s grasslands remain largely unknown. We show that soil health management practices that are commonly used in annual cropping systems can increase SOC storage in grasslands. These practices include reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and manure addition. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester SOC and provide a pathway for climate-smart agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a systematic approach to identifying and prioritizing the risk of spillover of novel viruses from wildlife. We developed a framework to assess the risk of spillover and spread of novel viruses in wildlife and used it to prioritize 887 viruses. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This approach can be applied to other emerging viral threats to inform research and public health interventions.

Nectar is a reward that many flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie this trait are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We identify the three enzymatic activities that are necessary for the production of this pigment. We also identify the same pigment in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae. Our findings suggest that the red pigment is a convergent trait that is favored by natural selection. This work provides insights into the evolution of a visually attractive trait in plants. It also highlights the importance of studying nectar chemistry in the study of pollination. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The history of Europe is marked by waves of immigration from outside the continent. However, the genetic history of the intervening periods is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had been deformed by cranial cranial deformation. Our data indicate that they had a genetic ancestry that was not represented in modern northern and central Europeans. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. The human genome is replicated in a process called DNA replication. This process is essential for the survival of the cell and the organism. The process is carried out by a complex of proteins called the replisome. The replisome is made up of several proteins, including DNA polymerase δ. The replisome is responsible for the synthesis of the lagging strand of the DNA. The lagging strand is the strand that is synthesized in the opposite direction of the replication fork. The replisome is responsible for the synthesis of the lagging strand of the DNA.
The origin of life is one of the most important questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the ability of RNA to replicate itself.

Urban change is a complex process that is difficult to observe and understand. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and to other types of urban change. We hope that it will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease. The clinical manifestations are diverse, and the mortality is high. The treatment is still in the stage of exploration. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is a promising treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal. The ability of fungi to regulate copper content is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is not. Here we describe the presence of a xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus, which is involved in copper homeostasis and has antimicrobial properties. The xanthocillin cluster is present in other filamentous fungi, suggesting a role for this gene cluster in fungal interactions with competing microbes. This study demonstrates the presence of a fungal natural product gene cluster involved in metal homeostasis and its role in interactions with competing microbes. The formation of silica in the martian environment is a key to understanding the origin and evolution of the planet. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant finding. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is possibly due to the cogenetic origin of the rock and the silicic volcanism in the region. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is also consistent with the diagenesis of high-SiO2 glass. The presence of amorphous mixed-cation salts and oxides and possibly the crystalline magnetite (otherwise detrital) are primary precipitates and/or their diagenesis products derived from multiple infiltrations of aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock at Gale crater, Mars, is a significant finding.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a key driver of economic losses in agriculture and forestry. However, the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the geographic distribution of plant species. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which is unable to induce colitis in a Th17 transfer model. This subset is dependent on the expression of the transcription factors T-bet and Stat4, and is required for the development of colitis. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms that give rise to these cells may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, and the mechanisms underlying the disease are not fully understood. We now report a method to rapidly and easily produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and to screen for drugs that can alleviate toxicity. This method will enable the study of the disease in a large number of patients and will lead to the development of new therapies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors plays a critical role in the transmission of infectious agents to vertebrate hosts. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the vector’s microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the tick’s gut microbiota and facilitates the pathogen’s transmission to vertebrate hosts. We demonstrate that the pathogen-encoded protein binds the d-alanine residue of bacterial peptidoglycan, which alters the permeability of the gut and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of arthropod microbiota and facilitate transmission to vertebrate hosts. This knowledge will be critical for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful animal lineages, and their evolution is a key topic in biology. However, the origin of the modern avian bauplan is still a matter of debate. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, which adds important information about the origin of the modern avian bauplan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. We show here that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal can be used to communicate with other animals, to hide from predators, or to attract mates. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein is present in many species, and it is most similar to human proteins that protect the body against inflammation. This discovery shows that the color of animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein, and it introduces a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms by which hypoxia promotes the growth of cancer cells are not fully understood. We show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is enriched in cancer stem cells, which are responsible for initiating tumor growth. Thus, our findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment from the past. (Show more)

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction event is critical for understanding the causes and mechanisms of the extinction and recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model shows that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization that preceded the extinction is punctuated by a sharp negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persisted for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. The new age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This work will also provide a new time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in the regulation of various biological processes. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium has not been well characterized. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression.
