The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and antiviral therapies. The D614G mutation is the most common substitution in currently circulating strains. We have determined the structure of the spike protein at 2.8 Å resolution and show that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike. This conformation may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent fusion with the host cell membrane. Our results provide insights into the impact of the D614G mutation on the structure and function of the spike protein. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced US life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. Our projections underscore the need for urgent action to address the structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.

The chemical properties of atoms are central to chemistry. However, there is no way to predict or even rationalize the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. Here, we introduce a new way to measure the chemical properties of atoms, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We show that our new measure of chemical properties is consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we show that our measure of chemical properties can be used to predict the behavior of atoms under pressure. This work is a step toward understanding the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Fire is a natural and anthropogenic disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems. Changes in fire activity can affect the global carbon cycle, but the trajectory of fire effects on climate is poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate, socioeconomic, and fire management changes on fire activity and carbon emissions. We find that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire management in climate mitigation and the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the feedbacks between climate, fire, and carbon.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their hosts. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. We show that the glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts, and that its catabolism modulates the pH of the symbiotic organ. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of how animals can regulate the activities of their symbionts. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly being used to understand the world around us. However, the latent patterns in text data are often difficult to identify. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as sequences of latent patterns. Our method is based on advances in machine learning and can be applied to a wide range of domains. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model latent patterns in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the Black Death, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that this assumption is not supported by the historical record. Instead, we find evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the disease was not permanently established in Europe, but rather was reintroduced periodically. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe. It also has implications for our understanding of the history of the Silk Road, which was the main trade route between Europe and Asia during the Middle Ages. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important prey for many species of marine animals. They are also a valuable food resource for humans. In recent years, a disease has been observed that has led to the mass mortality of asteroids. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. We also show that the virus is widespread in the environment and that it has been present in asteroids for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of new targets for therapy is urgently needed. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is a promising target for therapy of AML. We demonstrate that IL1RAP is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We further show that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can be used to treat primary human AML cells in vitro. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach could be used to treat a large number of AML patients, and the results presented here provide a proof of principle for this strategy. This approach could also be used to treat other diseases in which IL1RAP is expressed on disease-initiating cells. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a limited contribution of Europeans and Middle Easterners. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia happened independently. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a tool to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that increases the activity of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, a key enzyme in the metabolism of glycerol. We found that the RNA also represses two genes, cadA and galE, by base pairing with the RNA. The base pairing and AzuC translation compete for the same ribosome binding site, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their assessments are a key source of information for agricultural decision-making. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show how to convert the original qualitative data into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We demonstrate that the resulting index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of leveraging the knowledge of the local farming community to improve agricultural decision-making. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind information over time.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration measurements, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of experimental warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. This study adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The evolution of plastid genomes is a powerful tool to study the history of life on Earth. The molecular evolution of the plastid genome is shaped by the interplay between selection and drift. The evolutionary history of the plastid genome is therefore not only shaped by the evolutionary history of photosynthesis, but also by the evolutionary history of the host. We show that the evolutionary history of the plastid genome is shaped by the evolutionary history of the host.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water availability. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a first step towards quantifying the impact of climate change on water resources in SSA. However, more research is needed to understand the impact of the 2015–2017 drought on the local population. The discovery of quasicrystals has revolutionized condensed matter physics. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, is of historical interest because it represents the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal. The discovery of the conditions under which quasicrystals are formed, and the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems, are important steps toward understanding the nature of quasicrystals and their potential applications. Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth. It is powered by the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The conversion of the absorbed energy to chemical energy is mediated by the (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring of (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key step in this pathway. The mechanism of this reaction has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here, we describe the evolution of the enzymes involved in this reaction.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the roles of ASK1 in glial cells and the mechanisms underlying ASK1-mediated neuroinflammation remain largely unknown. Here, we report that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated the disease severity in EAE mice. We propose ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. Our findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for neurodegenerative diseases. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of ASK1 in neuroinflammation. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that the probability of drought has increased in recent decades because of human-caused global warming.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal genes and the causal pathways. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This study also provides a model system for studying the role of forgetting in learning and memory. (Show more)

This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people around the world react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, but they also highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. This variation is likely to be important for understanding the prevalence of negativity biases in the news media, and for understanding the potential for more positive content to influence public opinion. The results also suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein STIM1 and ORAI1, the two proteins that regulate store-operated Ca2+ entry, are associated with Stormorken syndrome. We show that the mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 result in gain- or gain-and-loss-of-function of the CRAC channel, respectively. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome and suggest new therapeutic strategies for patients with this disorder. This article is protected by copyright. Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we show that the polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin accumulates in the brain and spreads throughout the brain in a non–cell-autonomous manner. We show that this spreading is dependent on endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of neurodegenerative proteins and may lead to new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and the potential for MTX as a therapeutic target for the treatment of viral infections. Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the cell cycle is fueled by the one-carbon units provided by the folate cycle. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key regulator of the folate cycle, and its inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a series of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that these compounds are effective in vitro and in vivo, and that they are particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that one-carbon metabolism is a targetable metabolic deficiency of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These findings provide a platform for the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous motor neuron disease with a variety of genetic mutations. These mutations are linked to the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The proteins that form inclusions are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but are themselves supersaturated in motor neurons. This suggests that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a molecular explanation for the formation of inclusion bodies in ALS. It also provides a rationale for the use of small molecules that stabilize proteins in the metastable state. Such molecules could be used to treat ALS. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the early diversification of the flowering plants is, however, poorly understood. Here we present a detailed study of the early flowering plant Montsechia. The study of this plant, which is from the Cretaceous, raises questions about the very early diversification of the flowering plants.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. They are associated with a number of conditions in humans, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolution of parvoviruses has been estimated to be faster than that of RNA viruses, and it has been suggested that the most common parvovirus, genotype 1, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is ∼12.6 thousand years old, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Sea level is rising around the world. This rise is due to a combination of natural processes and human activities. The rate of sea level rise is accelerating, and the rate of acceleration is increasing. This acceleration is due to the same natural processes that are causing global warming.

Pain is a common and costly problem. In this paper, we show that pain is increasing in the United States, with tomorrow’s elderly reporting less pain than today’s elderly. This is a mystery. We show that the erosion of working-class life is the likely explanation.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of enzymology. The application of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy to the study of enzymes has been transformative, but the mechanistic insights that can be gained from NMR are often limited by the lack of a suitable crystal structure. Here, we describe the application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the study of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This study demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the structure and reactivity of an enzyme intermediate. This approach offers the potential to study a wide range of enzymes and their mechanisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the mortality rate is high. Remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, has shown promising results in vitro and in vivo against SARS-CoV. Here, we show that remdesivir is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in rhesus macaques. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also provides a model for the evaluation of antiviral drugs in a nonhuman primate model. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that a scalable, online intervention can reduce suspension rates by half. The intervention is simple: it teaches teachers to value students’ perspectives and sustain positive relationships while encouraging better behavior. This simple intervention has the potential to reduce suspension rates in US schools and, more generally, to improve the quality of teacher–student relationships.

DNA alkylation is a major cause of mutagenesis and genomic instability. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis. We found that the minor-groove alkylation of DNA is a major cause of transcriptional stalling. In addition, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. This study will help us to understand the molecular mechanisms of mutagenesis and genomic instability induced by alkylation. Furthermore, it will provide important information for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cancer and other diseases. This work will also help us to understand the molecular mechanisms of mutagenesis and genomic instability induced by alkylation.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a major impact on this. However, it is difficult to change people’s behavior. We show that it is possible to nudge people toward more sustainable diets by increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a cafeteria. This approach could be used in other settings, such as hospitals and schools.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. It is a dynamic and complex environment, and the cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to the cell surface of a panel of human breast epithelial cells expressing six of the most prominent oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface in cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has led to more than 50 million confirmed cases and over 1.2 million deaths worldwide. The virus has a large number of accessory proteins that are rapidly evolving, and it is unclear how these affect the severity of the disease. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness, but knowledge of its underlying mechanisms is limited. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces rat cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis and increases the expression of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. These effects, except for the increased expression of CRF itself, could all be blocked by pretreatment with an antagonist of the CRF receptor CRFR1. We also show that, in cultured primary astrocytes: (i) both CRFR1 and AQP4 are expressed; (ii) exogenous CRF, acting on CRFR1, triggers signaling of cAMP/PKA, intracellular Ca2+, and PKCε; and (iii) the up-regulated cAMP/PKA signaling contributes to the phosphorylation and expression of AQP4 to enhance water influx into astrocytes and produces an up-regulation of ET-1 expression. The world is full of associations. We are surrounded by them: the association between the weather and our mood, the association between our income and the number of cars we own, the association between the number of books we read and our IQ. We are also surrounded by associations that we are not aware of: the association between the number of books we read and our risk of cancer. In this paper, we describe a way of assessing the strength of associations that is needed in the era of big data.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs. ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is accompanied by the expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1. ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has opened up a new field of research. In this study, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also demonstrate that augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of photoreceptor cells that are involved in the regulation of pigmentation in the adult zebrafish. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This study provides insights into the physiological function of augmentor ligands and their link with Ltk. This work may also lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer and pigmentation disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem. Although the molecular mechanisms of T2D are well known, the molecular bases of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are still to be further elucidated. Herein, we show that STING is required for β-cell function and GSIS. We also show that STING deficiency in β-cells and insulin target tissues causes T2D. These findings provide a molecular basis for T2D and suggest that STING might be a potential therapeutic target for T2D. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of STING-based therapies for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human deaths due to an infectious disease. They are constantly evolving, and the emergence of new strains is a major concern. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of the viral particles. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and could help in the development of new antiviral strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The atheroprone disturbed flow is a key environmental factor that promotes the development of atherosclerotic lesions. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying the disturbed flow regulation of the atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions remain largely unknown. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow regulation of the atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study may also provide a molecular target for the development of athero-protective drugs. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have dramatically altered the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occur in regions with higher fuel moisture. Our findings highlight the importance of human activities in increasing the spatial and seasonal extent of wildfire, and suggest that actions to reduce fire risk should focus on reducing human-caused ignitions.

Urban change is a complex process that is difficult to observe and understand. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be applied to other cities and to other types of urban change. We hope that it will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV are likely important. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid growth of the virus and the presence of a short eclipse phase. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment and to assess the potential impact of a drug that blocks viral replication. Our results can help to inform the design of clinical trials and the development of new antiviral strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is triggered by heat stress. We show that the breakdown of the symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling and energy metabolism of the coral host. This, in turn, promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The intestinal epithelium is a major barrier between the host and the environment. It regulates the absorption of nutrients, mounts immune responses, and prevents systemic infections. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors. We demonstrate that the tumorigenic response is associated with the activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, which triggers a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismal lifespan extension. Our work identifies a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. It also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work may lead to the development of new strategies to control tumor growth and restore host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. We found that the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is expressed in a subset of breast cancers that are resistant to chemotherapy. ROR1 expression was associated with chemotherapy resistance and with the expression of genes that are induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1. ROR1 expression also enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is one of the most debated aspects of the last deglaciation. Here we show that the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is linked to a unique volcanic event, the Mount Takahe eruptions, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion. This event is unique in the last 40,000 y and is likely to have led to a change in Southern Hemisphere westerlies and climate.

Freshwater fisheries are a globally important source of food, recreation, and commerce. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with high levels of human-induced stress. We also show that inland fisheries are a critical source of protein for the world’s poor and malnourished. However, the high levels of fishing pressure in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management decisions to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of development and a valuable property for the adult nervous system. However, the regenerative capacity of the adult mammalian CNS is limited, and regeneration is lost after birth. Here, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of novel factors and signaling pathways that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which the genetic material of two parent genomes is mixed during the process of sexual reproduction. It is essential for the development of offspring, and it is also the source of genetic variation, which is the basis of evolution. The distribution of recombination across a genome is a fundamental characteristic of its genetic architecture. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination in a flowering plant, which is a major lineage of seed plants.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of interacting networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the organization of brain function. Here, we used a nonfluctuating imaging modality to identify and validate the resting organization of the brain. We show that the dominant resting network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant network in healthy subjects and during task performance. We show that the dominant network is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. Finally, we show that the dominant network is already present at diagnosis in Alzheimer’s disease, and that it progressively decreases in expression over time. This approach can be used to identify the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

RNA modifications are important for the regulation of gene expression. Here we describe a 5′ modification of RNA that is found in both the nucleus and the mitochondria of yeast cells. This modification is found on a subset of mRNAs and is not present on rRNA or tRNA. We show that this modification is not a pseudouridine, and we propose a mechanism for its formation. This modification may be important for the regulation of gene expression.

The study of the epigenetic mechanisms that regulate gene expression is a rapidly evolving field. In this study, we show that DNA methylation patterns at specific loci in blood cells are altered in people with diabetes and that these alterations persist over time. These findings support an epigenetic explanation for the metabolic memory phenomenon, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The study also provides a potential mechanism for the beneficial effects of intensive therapy on the progression of complications in people with diabetes. These findings may also have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of diabetes.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of a recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC and its mechanism of action are unknown. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it could be a previously unidentified target in the management of this disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals. These compounds are produced during fruit ripening, and the content of many of these compounds varies widely among different tomato species. Here we identify a gene essential for the production of a large number of these compounds. We show that this gene catalyzes the biosynthesis of a unique class of nitrogenous volatiles, and we identify the source of the nitrogen atoms in these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and it will be a valuable resource for the breeding of improved tomato cultivars. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of conservation and management strategies. They also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to the study of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit. It is thought to create a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. How these cell types are organized anatomically is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-moving behavior. We found that grid cells are strongly clustered, while border, HD, and OV cells tend to intermingle. These data suggest that grid cells might be largely distinct from those of other cell types. Our findings could have implications for understanding the organization of the MEC and its role in memory. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is not required for flowering of the host plant, but is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how a parasite may use flowering as a means to synchronize its own life cycle with that of its host.

The striatum is the major site of dopamine (DA) in the brain. The striatum is also the major target of the nigrostriatal pathway, the major route of DA from the substantivity nigra (SN) to the striatum. The SN is the major source of DA in the midbrain. We show that the striatum is also the major target of a second route of DA from the SN. This second route is the striatonigral pathway, which is thought to be important in the control of mood and motivation. We show that the striatonigral pathway is also important for the control of movement.

We are social creatures, and we are always looking for ways to connect with others. We have a robust metaphor for this connection: “to click.” But how do we know when two people are clicking? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust signal of connection. This signal is used by people themselves, and by others, to judge the quality of the connection between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that is able to adjust heart rate to meet hemodynamic demand. We report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the SAN. This work provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is a ubiquitous element in the environment, and its beneficial effects on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented. However, the role of Si in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, and that this effect is associated with an increase in jasmonate (JA) accumulation and defense responses. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism in macrophages. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of macrophages. They also suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity may be a promising approach for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can bind information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can bind information over time. Plants are sessile organisms and are dependent on external inputs for their growth and development. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task, and the delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNA is even more difficult. Herein, we report a systematic assessment of DNA nanostructures for their ability to deliver RNA across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the RNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery of RNA across the cell wall. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering RNA across the cell wall of plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be useful for the development of RNA-based therapeutics in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient pollution from small tributaries is a growing concern for coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, the relative importance of small tributaries has been overlooked in many studies, despite their ubiquity. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large water bodies. Our findings reveal that small watersheds can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas, especially in large water bodies. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies to improve our understanding of the relative importance of small tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small subset of the network’s chemical concentrations. We find that the system’s dynamics are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environment’s forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the universe’s initial conditions are biased toward states that extremize the cosmological constant. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning of the chemical network may be a manifestation of the same underlying physical principle.

Autoimmune encephalitis is a rare disorder in which the immune system attacks the brain. The most common form, NMDAR-Ab encephalitis, is characterized by seizures and paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab antibodies change the dynamics of the brain’s electrical activity, which in turn can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. This mechanism may be relevant to the clinical presentation of patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Our findings may also have implications for other autoimmune encephalitis disorders. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid climate change. To understand the Earth system response to abrupt climate change, it is important to understand the history of abrupt climate change in the past. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred ∼304 Ma during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in organic matter burial and to anoxia of the ocean.

Certification of palm oil production is a major tool for reducing tropical deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation and fire remains unclear. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, most certified areas contained little residual forest when certification was granted. Moreover, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. It is essential to organisms across kingdoms. However, the molecular mechanism of its regulation is still unknown. Here, we discovered a small molecule that binds to the exocyst complex and inhibits exocytosis. This study provides a valuable tool for studying the regulation of the exocyst complex and a potential drug target for human disease. This study also demonstrates the power of using a small molecule to study the regulation of a protein complex. This approach can be extended to other protein complexes. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination alleles is a major driver of phenotypic variation in animals. In many vertebrates, sex determination is a single-locus process, resulting in two sexes and two sexes only. However, in many other vertebrates, sex determination is polygenic, with multiple alleles segregating within a single species. Here we show that the polygenic sex determination system in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii produces a modular system of secondary sexual characteristics, with the potential for variation in traits such as genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behavior. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. This modularity may be a general feature of polygenic sex determination.

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue, and the retina is also challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating adducts of vitamin A. We sought to understand how the levels of iron, a key component of the Fenton chemistry that generates reactive oxygen species, impacts the retina. We found that iron promotes the oxidation and degradation of a class of adducts of vitamin A that are known to contribute to the loss of photoreceptor cells. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that the levels of iron in the retina may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of this disease. (Read more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the functioning of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that this is not the case in the case of siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators that use their tentacles to capture prey. We show that siphonophores can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have directly evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also contribute to the understanding of the evolution of specialization in predators.

The evolution of the human hand is a key question in human evolution. Despite the discovery of relatively complete hands from two early hominin species and partial hands from another, fundamental questions remain about the evolution of the human hand. This is driven by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the modern human hand, was present ∼1.42 My old in an East African hominin from Kaitio, West Turkana, Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit pathway, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is a promising therapeutic target for cancer, but its dual function in the mitochondria makes it difficult to target. Here we identify a small-molecule inhibitor of both SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in a subset of cancer cells. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer cells. This work provides a metabolic mechanism for cancer cell growth, and a potential therapeutic target. This work also provides a metabolic mechanism for cancer cell growth, and a potential therapeutic target.

The world is facing a triple challenge of food, nutrition, and environmental security. This study shows that natural landscapes such as forests can contribute to meeting these goals. We show that deforestation can reduce people’s diets and vitamin A adequacy, and that forest fragmentation can increase people’s diets and vitamin A adequacy. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also shows that the use of causal inference methods is important to understand the impact of deforestation on people’s diets. This study is a first step in understanding the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals.

Modern farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural production, but at the cost of higher vehicle weights that have led to compaction of soil layers below the surface. We show that the increase in vehicle weight has led to the propagation of compaction into deeper soil layers, with a high risk of subsoil compaction in 20% of arable land. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis needs to be tested. (Show more)
